content.description: This lies on the left arete of the backside of the Mr. Ed Boulder. Start as low as you can pull yourself onto the ledge and traverse over to the apex. Top out.
content.protection: Pad; there is a troublesome rock in the landing.
content.location:
This lies on the Mr. Ed Boulder about 2/3rds of a mile up the Big Wash trail. Mr. Ed is about 100 yards before

Honeycomb

.

content.description:
This is a cool traverse on a very peculiar rock. Start with hands matched on the bottom left corner of the creek face of Honeycomb Boulder. Traverse almost all the way around the boulder and top out. The crux is near the beginning. Once you have rounded the corner to the backside, the movement eases to 4th class for a moment before the final challenging section. Finish all the way on the arete to the right.

The honeycomb texture one this rock is crazy to look at but makes for sharp climbing holds. The rock is also very brittle, so use a good spotter. Weird knobs provide plenty of platforms for your feet. This crazy route is fun for the grade, and the odd rock makes it worthwhile. It probably deserves 2.5 stars for being lengthy, unique, and interesting, but it is brittle, sharp, and out of the way.
content.protection: Pad and competent spotter. I suppose I should also add tape for your fingers, too.
content.location: This lies on the Honeycomb Boulder about 2/3rds of a mile up Big Wash Trail.

content.description: Sit start on the bottom right of the Mr. Ed Boulder's backside. Using thin holds, pull yourself up to the crest and traverse left to the top.
content.protection: Pad; there is a troublesome rock directly beneath the crux.
content.location: This lies on the backside of Mr. Ed Boulder.
